Ping Pong Policy

Richard Nixon and the strange "Ping-Pong diplomacy."

A 'fake' website by Milan Donhowe for Period 2 20th Century History using a website template from Colorlib.

1971 The Year
0 Years of Diplomatic Silence
2 Ping Pong Teams
5143 Reasons to give Milan an A+.

The Cold Relations

Ever since the Communist Party of China took control in 1949 relations between the United States and China had been relatively non-existent. Considering this was during the thick of the cold war, the United States wasn’t super psyched to form diplomatic ties with a communist government. Conversely, the CPC didn’t really want to negotiate with a capitalist country, especially one that was the mortal enemy of their closest ally at the time, the USSR. As such, for 20 years not a single US diplomat actually stepped foot into China. There was no communication between the two nations and it seemed like it might stay that way for decades to come.

Until the USSR and China broke up. After a series of border skirmishes, disagreements in ideology and the recalling of diplomatic allies, China was severed from what was effectively their only (useful) ally. Mao realizing that China had basically zero allies and was mostly cut off from the rest of the globe, was now suddenly open to the idea of forming new diplomatic ties, even with their mortal enemy, the United States.

Nixon already had wanted to open up more diplomatic ties with China and had Henry Kissinger begin secret communications with Zhou Enlai, the premier of the People’s Republic of China (PRC). The will between the two countries was there, all that was now needed was a push.

PING PONG

In 1971 such a push was granted when a air headed US teenager Glenn Cowan, a member of the US national Ping Pong team at the world championship in Japan, jumped onto the bus carrying the Chinese Team to the tournament. While the Chinese players had been told to explicitly ignore the American Players at the tournament, one player Zhang Zedong must’ve forgotten this cherished advice as he befriended Glenn, giving him a gift of a beautiful picture of the Chinese mountains; in return for this thoughtful and delightful gift Glenn gave the chinese player a beatles t-shirt. How thoughtful of Glenn.

However small this gesture may have actually been it was just the opening move needed for Mao to open a dialogue between China and the US. Mao invited the US Ping Pong team to China for a tour and some games. The games played were televised in the US and immediately followed by Nixon visiting China to meet with Mao Zedong. From there, history gets a lot more boring.

What Happened (Timeline left to right)

The 1971 Ping Pong World Championship

Glenn Cowan, a US Ping-Pong player befriended Zhang Zedong, a Chinese Ping-Pong player at the 1971 Ping Pong World Championship.

US Team Invited to China

The US Ping-Pong team was then invited to tour China and play some games against the Chinese Players.

Nixon Visits China.

Nixon about a year later in 1972 visited China. This was the first time a President of the United States actually stepped foot into the country while in office.

Nixon Did a Handshake With Mao.

The Shanghai Communique Written

After Nixon visited China the countries wrote "The Shanghai Communique", a document announcing both countries intention to continue the normalization of relations. The writers of IB textbooks were excited.

The Impacts

  • China replaced Tai-Wan on the UN Security Council.
  • Travel bans between both countries were revoked.
  • Relations were opened between the countries for future agreements and trade deals.
  • Nixon temporarily distracted people from thinking that he was a crook.
